trans-unit.source: How to authorize developer accounts using OAuth 2.0 in Azure API Management
trans-unit.target: How to authorize developer accounts using OAuth 2.0 in Azure API Management

trans-unit.source: Learn how to authorize users using OAuth 2.0 in API Management.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to authorize users using OAuth 2.0 in API Management.

trans-unit.source: How to authorize developer accounts using OAuth 2.0 in Azure API Management
trans-unit.target: How to authorize developer accounts using OAuth 2.0 in Azure API Management

trans-unit.source: Many APIs support [OAuth 2.0](http://oauth.net/2/) to secure the API and ensure that only valid users have access, and they can only access resources to which they're entitled.
trans-unit.target: Many APIs support [OAuth 2.0](http://oauth.net/2/) to secure the API and ensure that only valid users have access, and they can only access resources to which they're entitled.

trans-unit.source: In order to use Azure API Management's interactive Developer Console with such APIs, the service allows you to configure your service instance to work with your OAuth 2.0 enabled API.
trans-unit.target: In order to use Azure API Management's interactive Developer Console with such APIs, the service allows you to configure your service instance to work with your OAuth 2.0 enabled API.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: This guide shows you how to configure your API Management service instance to use OAuth 2.0 authorization for developer accounts, but does not show you how to configure an OAuth 2.0 provider.
trans-unit.target: This guide shows you how to configure your API Management service instance to use OAuth 2.0 authorization for developer accounts, but does not show you how to configure an OAuth 2.0 provider.

trans-unit.source: The configuration for each OAuth 2.0 provider is different, although the steps are similar, and the required pieces of information used in configuring OAuth 2.0 in your API Management service instance are the same.
trans-unit.target: The configuration for each OAuth 2.0 provider is different, although the steps are similar, and the required pieces of information used in configuring OAuth 2.0 in your API Management service instance are the same.

trans-unit.source: This topic shows examples using Azure Active Directory as an OAuth 2.0 provider.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows examples using Azure Active Directory as an OAuth 2.0 provider.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] For more information on configuring OAuth 2.0 using Azure Active Directory, see the [WebApp-GraphAPI-DotNet][] sample.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] For more information on configuring OAuth 2.0 using Azure Active Directory, see the [WebApp-GraphAPI-DotNet][] sample.

trans-unit.source: Configure an OAuth 2.0 authorization server in API Management
trans-unit.target: Configure an OAuth 2.0 authorization server in API Management

trans-unit.source: To get started, click **Manage** in the Azure Portal for your API Management service.
trans-unit.target: To get started, click **Manage** in the Azure Portal for your API Management service.

trans-unit.source: This takes you to the API Management publisher portal.
trans-unit.target: This takes you to the API Management publisher portal.

trans-unit.source: Publisher portal
trans-unit.target: Publisher portal

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you have not yet created an API Management service instance, see [Create an API Management service instance][] in the [Get started with Azure API Management][] tutorial.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you have not yet created an API Management service instance, see [Create an API Management service instance][] in the [Get started with Azure API Management][] tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Click **Security** from the **API Management** menu on the left, click **OAuth 2.0**, and then click **Add authorization server**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Security** from the **API Management** menu on the left, click **OAuth 2.0**, and then click **Add authorization server**.

trans-unit.source: OAuth 2.0
trans-unit.target: OAuth 2.0

trans-unit.source: After clicking **Add authorization server**, the new authorization server form is displayed.
trans-unit.target: After clicking **Add authorization server**, the new authorization server form is displayed.

trans-unit.source: New server
trans-unit.target: New server

trans-unit.source: Enter a name and an optional description in the **Name** and **Description** fields.
trans-unit.target: Enter a name and an optional description in the **Name** and **Description** fields.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] These fields are used to identify the OAuth 2.0 authorization server within the current API Management service instance and their values do not come from the OAuth 2.0 server.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] These fields are used to identify the OAuth 2.0 authorization server within the current API Management service instance and their values do not come from the OAuth 2.0 server.

trans-unit.source: Enter the **Client registration page URL**.
trans-unit.target: Enter the **Client registration page URL**.

trans-unit.source: This page is where users can create and manage their accounts, and varies depending on the OAuth 2.0 provider used.
trans-unit.target: This page is where users can create and manage their accounts, and varies depending on the OAuth 2.0 provider used.

trans-unit.source: The **Client registration page URL** points to the page that users can use to create and configure their own accounts for OAuth 2.0 providers that support user management of accounts.
trans-unit.target: The **Client registration page URL** points to the page that users can use to create and configure their own accounts for OAuth 2.0 providers that support user management of accounts.

trans-unit.source: Some organizations do not configure or use this functionality even if the OAuth 2.0 provider supports it.
trans-unit.target: Some organizations do not configure or use this functionality even if the OAuth 2.0 provider supports it.

trans-unit.source: If your OAuth 2.0 provider does not have user management of accounts configured, enter a placeholder URL here such as the URL of your company, or a URL such as `https://placeholder.contoso.com`.
trans-unit.target: If your OAuth 2.0 provider does not have user management of accounts configured, enter a placeholder URL here such as the URL of your company, or a URL such as `https://placeholder.contoso.com`.

trans-unit.source: The next section of the form contains the **Authorization code grant types**, **Authorization endpoint URL**, and **Authorization request method** settings.
trans-unit.target: The next section of the form contains the **Authorization code grant types**, **Authorization endpoint URL**, and **Authorization request method** settings.

trans-unit.source: New server
trans-unit.target: New server

trans-unit.source: Specify the **Authorization code grant types** by checking the desired types.
trans-unit.target: Specify the **Authorization code grant types** by checking the desired types.

trans-unit.source: **Authorization code** is specified by default.
trans-unit.target: **Authorization code** is specified by default.

trans-unit.source: Enter the **Authorization endpoint URL**.
trans-unit.target: Enter the **Authorization endpoint URL**.

trans-unit.source: For Azure Active Directory, this URL will be similar to the following URL, where `<client_id>` is replaced with the client id that identifies your application to the OAuth 2.0 server.
trans-unit.target: For Azure Active Directory, this URL will be similar to the following URL, where `<client_id>` is replaced with the client id that identifies your application to the OAuth 2.0 server.

trans-unit.source: The **Authorization request method** specifies how the authorization request is sent to the OAuth 2.0 server.
trans-unit.target: The **Authorization request method** specifies how the authorization request is sent to the OAuth 2.0 server.

trans-unit.source: By default **GET** is selected.
trans-unit.target: By default **GET** is selected.

trans-unit.source: The next section is where the **Token endpoint URL**, **Client authentication methods**, **Access token sending method**, and **Default scope** are specified.
trans-unit.target: The next section is where the **Token endpoint URL**, **Client authentication methods**, **Access token sending method**, and **Default scope** are specified.

trans-unit.source: New server
trans-unit.target: New server

trans-unit.source: For an Azure Active Directory OAuth 2.0 server, the **Token endpoint URL** will have the following format, where `<APPID>` has the format of `yourapp.onmicrosoft.com`.
trans-unit.target: For an Azure Active Directory OAuth 2.0 server, the **Token endpoint URL** will have the following format, where `<APPID>` has the format of `yourapp.onmicrosoft.com`.

trans-unit.source: The default setting for **Client authentication methods** is **Basic**, and **Access token sending method** is **Authorization header**.
trans-unit.target: The default setting for **Client authentication methods** is **Basic**, and **Access token sending method** is **Authorization header**.

trans-unit.source: These values are configured on this section of the form, along with the **Default scope**.
trans-unit.target: These values are configured on this section of the form, along with the **Default scope**.

trans-unit.source: The **Client credentials** section contains the **Client ID** and **Client secret**, which are obtained during the creation and configuration process of your OAuth 2.0 server.
trans-unit.target: The **Client credentials** section contains the **Client ID** and **Client secret**, which are obtained during the creation and configuration process of your OAuth 2.0 server.

trans-unit.source: Once the **Client ID** and **Client secret** are specified, the **redirect_uri** for the **authorization code** is generated.
trans-unit.target: Once the **Client ID** and **Client secret** are specified, the **redirect_uri** for the **authorization code** is generated.

trans-unit.source: This URI is used to configure the reply URL in your OAuth 2.0 server configuration.
trans-unit.target: This URI is used to configure the reply URL in your OAuth 2.0 server configuration.

trans-unit.source: New server
trans-unit.target: New server

trans-unit.source: If **Authorization code grant types** is set to **Resource owner password**, the **Resource owner password credentials** section is used to specify those credentials; otherwise you can leave it blank.
trans-unit.target: If **Authorization code grant types** is set to **Resource owner password**, the **Resource owner password credentials** section is used to specify those credentials; otherwise you can leave it blank.

trans-unit.source: New server
trans-unit.target: New server

trans-unit.source: Once the form is complete, click **Save** to save the API Management OAuth 2.0 authorization server configuration.
trans-unit.target: Once the form is complete, click **Save** to save the API Management OAuth 2.0 authorization server configuration.

trans-unit.source: Once the server configuration is saved, you can configure APIs to use this configuration, as shown in the next section.
trans-unit.target: Once the server configuration is saved, you can configure APIs to use this configuration, as shown in the next section.

trans-unit.source: Configure an API to use OAuth 2.0 user authorization
trans-unit.target: Configure an API to use OAuth 2.0 user authorization

trans-unit.source: Click **APIs** from the **API Management** menu on the left, click the name of the desired API, click **Security**, and then check the box for **OAuth 2.0**.
trans-unit.target: Click **APIs** from the **API Management** menu on the left, click the name of the desired API, click **Security**, and then check the box for **OAuth 2.0**.

trans-unit.source: User authorization
trans-unit.target: User authorization

trans-unit.source: Select the desired **Authorization server** from the drop-down list, and click **Save**.
trans-unit.target: Select the desired **Authorization server** from the drop-down list, and click **Save**.

trans-unit.source: User authorization
trans-unit.target: User authorization

trans-unit.source: Test the OAuth 2.0 user authorization in the Developer Portal
trans-unit.target: Test the OAuth 2.0 user authorization in the Developer Portal

trans-unit.source: Once you have configured your OAuth 2.0 authorization server and configured your API to use that server, you can test it by going to the Developer Portal and calling an API.
trans-unit.target: Once you have configured your OAuth 2.0 authorization server and configured your API to use that server, you can test it by going to the Developer Portal and calling an API.

trans-unit.source: Click **Developer portal** in the top right menu.
trans-unit.target: Click **Developer portal** in the top right menu.

trans-unit.source: Developer portal
trans-unit.target: Developer portal

trans-unit.source: Click **APIs** in the top menu and select **Echo API**.
trans-unit.target: Click **APIs** in the top menu and select **Echo API**.

trans-unit.source: Echo API
trans-unit.target: Echo API

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you have only one API configured or visible to your account, then clicking APIs takes you directly to the operations for that API.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you have only one API configured or visible to your account, then clicking APIs takes you directly to the operations for that API.

trans-unit.source: Select the **GET Resource** operation, click **Open Console**, and then select **Authorization code** from the drop-down.
trans-unit.target: Select the **GET Resource** operation, click **Open Console**, and then select **Authorization code** from the drop-down.

trans-unit.source: Open console
trans-unit.target: Open console

trans-unit.source: When **Authorization code** is selected, a pop-up window is displayed with the sign-in form of the OAuth 2.0 provider.
trans-unit.target: When **Authorization code** is selected, a pop-up window is displayed with the sign-in form of the OAuth 2.0 provider.

trans-unit.source: In this example the sign-in form is provided by Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: In this example the sign-in form is provided by Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you have pop-ups disabled you will be prompted to enable them by the browser.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you have pop-ups disabled you will be prompted to enable them by the browser.

trans-unit.source: After you enable them, select **Authorization code** again and the sign-in form will be displayed.
trans-unit.target: After you enable them, select **Authorization code** again and the sign-in form will be displayed.

trans-unit.source: Sign in
trans-unit.target: Sign in

trans-unit.source: Once you have signed in, the **Request headers** are populated with an `Authorization : Bearer` header that authorizes the request.
trans-unit.target: Once you have signed in, the **Request headers** are populated with an `Authorization : Bearer` header that authorizes the request.

trans-unit.source: Request header token
trans-unit.target: Request header token

trans-unit.source: At this point you can configure the desired values for the remaining parameters, and submit the request.
trans-unit.target: At this point you can configure the desired values for the remaining parameters, and submit the request.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: For more information about using OAuth 2.0 and API Management, see the following video and accompanying [article](api-management-howto-protect-backend-with-aad.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about using OAuth 2.0 and API Management, see the following video and accompanying [article](api-management-howto-protect-backend-with-aad.md).

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
